componenttext: So just bigger picture, thinking, allowing the charge-off to move at a rate that's greater than the provision, how should we kind of be thinking about that going forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, the provision or the reserve that we have on the balance sheet as compared to our asset base has actually picked up a little bit. Progressively each quarter, just to maintain our conservative reserve position as we always do. So we were essentia
componenttext: Actually, the provision or the reserve that we have on the balance sheet as compared to our asset base has actually picked up a little bit. Progressively each quarter, just to maintain our conservative reserve position as we always do. So we were essentially at 2.5% of our asset base at the end of the first quarter.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kristine Kubacki with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kristine Kubacki with Avondale Partners.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is a little bit more color on the new engine production. I know you said this summer, but I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more detail about the process of bringing up production and where you are now in terms of ramp up? And
componenttext: My question is a little bit more color on the new engine production. I know you said this summer, but I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more detail about the process of bringing up production and where you are now in terms of ramp up? And then you mentioned the 1,500 orders. I was kind of wondering just over the longer term, where the mix of your volume is going to come more of the 30-liter versus 15-liter? Kind of what's your goal mix there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, for the foreseeable future, we'll be selling more 15 liters with our excellent partner, Commons. We only have a 9 liter and a 13-liter in house, so that's what we'll sell. And in terms of the ramp up, it's -- the summer is the time frame
componenttext: Well, certainly, for the foreseeable future, we'll be selling more 15 liters with our excellent partner, Commons. We only have a 9 liter and a 13-liter in house, so that's what we'll sell. And in terms of the ramp up, it's -- the summer is the time frame that we're aiming for. And I think over time, we'll see a good balance between the 13-liter PACCAR engine and the 15-liter Commons engine to serve the whole market, customers will get the benefit.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of summer, will that be late summer or more mid or early Summer?
componenttext: In terms of summer, will that be late summer or more mid or early Summer?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say in the middle of the summer.
componenttext: I'd say in the middle of the summer.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I wanted to ask a question about the pricing, maybe a little bit differently. We've been hearing the same things on pricing, especially on the 2010 engines, coming under a little bit of pressure. I wanted to get your sense on what are you seeing
componenttext: And then I wanted to ask a question about the pricing, maybe a little bit differently. We've been hearing the same things on pricing, especially on the 2010 engines, coming under a little bit of pressure. I wanted to get your sense on what are you seeing competitors doing at this time? I realize it's pretty low volumes, that's pretty hard to make kind of long-range forecast based on this. But what are you seeing from competitors and do you think that the industry will be able to hold the line on the pricing? Or do you think that as volume improves, we'll start to see the industry pushing back on trucking companies with that pricing?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a very normal process. Most of our competitors are still trying to sell pre-2010 engines. Just to say we're the leader on selling the 2010 engine. Over time, most of the pricing will be passed through as our customers pass through the additio
componenttext: I think it's a very normal process. Most of our competitors are still trying to sell pre-2010 engines. Just to say we're the leader on selling the 2010 engine. Over time, most of the pricing will be passed through as our customers pass through the additional cost to their customer, that's a pretty normal way the market works. But that will take some time. It will certainly take all of this year to work through, particularly since we're introducing higher priced but more efficient product in an ongoing recession. If it was boom times, it would be a slightly different economic scenario. But we're coming out of a very challenging recession, so customers and their customers are more wary and more conscious of cost and what they can or cannot pass through.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: A short-term question, you mentioned that your competitors have more 2009 engines available. Do you think you'll see market share shifts here in the short-term as they're running those out and you may see a lower production?
componenttext: A short-term question, you mentioned that your competitors have more 2009 engines available. Do you think you'll see market share shifts here in the short-term as they're running those out and you may see a lower production?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, that's pretty normal. A number of our competitors are interested in market share. Usually at the detriment of their shareholders, I find. But that's pretty normal. And after time, it all balances out.
componenttext: I think, that's pretty normal. A number of our competitors are interested in market share. Usually at the detriment of their shareholders, I find. But that's pretty normal. And after time, it all balances out.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, you always lean over the inventory supply chain as anyone, I'm wondering if you can talk about how you see the freight situation in Europe playing out for truckers? How much higher have spot truck rates moved and over what time period do you think t
componenttext: Mark, you always lean over the inventory supply chain as anyone, I'm wondering if you can talk about how you see the freight situation in Europe playing out for truckers? How much higher have spot truck rates moved and over what time period do you think that situation is resolved, if aerospace opens up over the next couple of days?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have sort of what the freight spot has done just over the last four days because of the Icelandic volcano. But the vast majority of rate does get moved by truck as you know. So there might have been a momentary, one week upward movement. I think t
componenttext: I don't have sort of what the freight spot has done just over the last four days because of the Icelandic volcano. But the vast majority of rate does get moved by truck as you know. So there might have been a momentary, one week upward movement. I think that will settle back down. So we're starting to see freight rates lightly improve but I'd say slightly in Europe. And there's still a lot of economic challenges and you got a number of countries that have elections going on, the U.K. and the Netherlands come to mind. And then you have Spain, Portugal and Italy that are probably having a little more serious economic challenges. Central Europe is sort of being impacted in a negative way. So there's lots of things going on there. It's going to take some time to settle out. The good news is that people love the DAF Trucks and they're buying those but certainly not at the levels we saw two, three years ago.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And Mark, in terms of the parts of Europe or countries that you're more optimistic on this year, can you talk about which countries are at the top of that list?
componenttext: And Mark, in terms of the parts of Europe or countries that you're more optimistic on this year, can you talk about which countries are at the top of that list?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think primarily Northern and Western Europe. So France, Germany, Netherlands, Belgium would be some of our strongest markets.
componenttext: Well, I think primarily Northern and Western Europe. So France, Germany, Netherlands, Belgium would be some of our strongest markets.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And Mark, the order trends that you're seeing in the European market, obviously, it's a great sign that you're taking up production rates. Can you just talk about where orders tracked in the first quarter perhaps relative to sales?
componenttext: And Mark, the order trends that you're seeing in the European market, obviously, it's a great sign that you're taking up production rates. Can you just talk about where orders tracked in the first quarter perhaps relative to sales?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the orders have improved. We're taking some share away from probably one of our German competitors. It seems to be in a little bit of a disarray. But having been in this business for many decades, what will probably happen is once our competitors fi
componenttext: Well, the orders have improved. We're taking some share away from probably one of our German competitors. It seems to be in a little bit of a disarray. But having been in this business for many decades, what will probably happen is once our competitors figure out their internal business systems, they'll aggressively come out with low prices to regain or regain some of the share that they lost. And we'll go back to the steady progress that DAF's made over the last, almost 15 years of -- a few tenths or half a tenth or half a point of share increase over the year. So I think it's kind of what we're seeing right now in Europe.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And Mark, lastly, just a clarifying question, your earlier comment that commodity cost inflation, you'd have to offset through internal initiatives. Does that apply to both U.S. and European market, or is there a chance that your European competitors migh
componenttext: And Mark, lastly, just a clarifying question, your earlier comment that commodity cost inflation, you'd have to offset through internal initiatives. Does that apply to both U.S. and European market, or is there a chance that your European competitors might push prices with the romas [ph] move?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the commodities are worldwide. So everybody who manufactures anywhere in the world will be impacted by the base commodity increases. Europe doesn't have the 2010 engine increase. But I think the competitors will probably keep their pricing at relati
componenttext: Well, the commodities are worldwide. So everybody who manufactures anywhere in the world will be impacted by the base commodity increases. Europe doesn't have the 2010 engine increase. But I think the competitors will probably keep their pricing at relatively low levels to maintain whatever share they've got. And they've had several years of losses and I think they're probably comfortable to have several more years of losses, as long as they can keep their share from going. So it's pretty normal in many ways.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Patrick Nolan with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Patrick Nolan with Deutsche Bank.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at your R&D and your CapEx spending in the quarter, I would've thought they would had been more front-end loaded given the ramp ups that are marching the '10 engines in mid-year?
componenttext: When I look at your R&D and your CapEx spending in the quarter, I would've thought they would had been more front-end loaded given the ramp ups that are marching the '10 engines in mid-year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the expense and capital and R&D for the engines has been on the previous couple of years or previous three, four, five years. What is now shifting because we're in very good shape in terms of 2010 engines, is the ongoing development of just
componenttext: Well, a lot of the expense and capital and R&D for the engines has been on the previous couple of years or previous three, four, five years. What is now shifting because we're in very good shape in terms of 2010 engines, is the ongoing development of just new vehicle products. So we're actually sort of in a bit of a transition right now. I think you saw some of that at the Mid-America show. So the engine expenditures has really been dialed down because we've done the work.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And how are you thinking about, I mean, it looks like production is increasing and you're now pretty steady to increasing in North America. You're still generating cash and have $2 billion on the balance sheet. How are you thinking about what you're going
componenttext: And how are you thinking about, I mean, it looks like production is increasing and you're now pretty steady to increasing in North America. You're still generating cash and have $2 billion on the balance sheet. How are you thinking about what you're going to do with your cash relative to your dividend last year? I know that's a Board decision. But what are the priorities for cash going forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think just for the first point on the production, as we've indicated, North America, Kenworth and Peterbilt production will most likely be down this year. So that's an important factor to take into account. We've got a very strong balance sheet, which i
componenttext: I think just for the first point on the production, as we've indicated, North America, Kenworth and Peterbilt production will most likely be down this year. So that's an important factor to take into account. We've got a very strong balance sheet, which is really one of the major factors that's contributed to us being able to make any money last year, and being able to borrow money for our finance companies and the treasury team has done an outstanding job on that. The dividend is something that we continue to review with the Board and we made that difficult decision a year ago. And as the business improves, we certainly would like to take a serious look at improving the dividend or looking at opportunities in South America. We're looking at opportunities in Asia and we also have got a pretty active new product development program that will use some of that cash. So plenty of opportunities to invest.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So we should not expect any benefit of utilization rates in Europe from the North American engine in the second quarter because that's more mid-summer, at the end of the summer. So that's really going to be Q3 and beyond right?
componenttext: So we should not expect any benefit of utilization rates in Europe from the North American engine in the second quarter because that's more mid-summer, at the end of the summer. So that's really going to be Q3 and beyond right?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: For engines?
componenttext: For engines?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as improved utilization rates and the European...
componenttext: As far as improved utilization rates and the European...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: DAF has an excellent engine factory but there are relatively low production compared to the capacity of our engine factory. So it will be minor enhancement to utilization and efficiency.
componenttext: DAF has an excellent engine factory but there are relatively low production compared to the capacity of our engine factory. So it will be minor enhancement to utilization and efficiency.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'm just a little bit confused on the outlet for Q2 North America production. You said that you're in effect almost out of 2009 engines. However, your 2010 MX engines have not been certified yet. So can you help clarify what will you be building ? W
componenttext: Mark, I'm just a little bit confused on the outlet for Q2 North America production. You said that you're in effect almost out of 2009 engines. However, your 2010 MX engines have not been certified yet. So can you help clarify what will you be building ? Will you be building uncertified. . .

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, but I always love your questions. We're Cummins' largest customer. We have a great strong partnership. We'll be selling a lot of Cummins engines.
componenttext: No, but I always love your questions. We're Cummins' largest customer. We have a great strong partnership. We'll be selling a lot of Cummins engines.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So not just 15-liter?
componenttext: So not just 15-liter?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, Cummins has a whole range of engines.
componenttext: No, Cummins has a whole range of engines.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So you will not be assembling PACCAR trucks, Kenworth and Peterbilt trucks with MX engines until they are certified. I was just kind of wondering if you could be building the engines in the inventory.
componenttext: So you will not be assembling PACCAR trucks, Kenworth and Peterbilt trucks with MX engines until they are certified. I was just kind of wondering if you could be building the engines in the inventory.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: The EPA certification is a very normal two-step process. The first step is complete. Passed great and we're in process on the second step and we're looking for certification in May.
componenttext: The EPA certification is a very normal two-step process. The first step is complete. Passed great and we're in process on the second step and we're looking for certification in May.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then there are 1,500 orders for 2010 engines. Can you talk just a little bit about what your expectations might have been, is this in line with what your expectations might have been? Is it below, is it above?
componenttext: And then there are 1,500 orders for 2010 engines. Can you talk just a little bit about what your expectations might have been, is this in line with what your expectations might have been? Is it below, is it above?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: It's in line. These are 1,500 MX engine orders and I think it's in line and we look for a few more thousands as we go through over the next several months. And obviously, it's an engine that's had very good results and all the rigorous testing we've done.
componenttext: It's in line. These are 1,500 MX engine orders and I think it's in line and we look for a few more thousands as we go through over the next several months. And obviously, it's an engine that's had very good results and all the rigorous testing we've done. I think you have picked up that 50 million miles of testing. So we're excited by getting them out into the field and having our customers enjoy the benefits.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're reiterating that miles tested is an important criteria?
componenttext: So you're reiterating that miles tested is an important criteria?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think everybody in the automotive industry would corroborate that.
componenttext: I think everybody in the automotive industry would corroborate that.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, just a detail. The Southern and North America then as you transition out of '09 engines and into 2010 engines in Q2, versus maybe a slight pick up in Europe. Net-net, if you look at the net impact, would you expect revenues sequenti
componenttext: And then just finally, just a detail. The Southern and North America then as you transition out of '09 engines and into 2010 engines in Q2, versus maybe a slight pick up in Europe. Net-net, if you look at the net impact, would you expect revenues sequentially to be down or flat in Q2?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say flat to maybe slightly up.
componenttext: I'd say flat to maybe slightly up.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Flat to slightly up, overall?
componenttext: Flat to slightly up, overall?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Robert W. Baird.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually, you got Keith Schicker calling in for Dave. I wanted to touched on used truck prices. Prices are rising in the U.S. Could you comment on the used truck environment in Europe, and then also we saw as used truck prices were depressed and pote
componenttext: It's actually, you got Keith Schicker calling in for Dave. I wanted to touched on used truck prices. Prices are rising in the U.S. Could you comment on the used truck environment in Europe, and then also we saw as used truck prices were depressed and potentially some lenders were a little reluctant to repossess trucks. Could you comment on how that looks right now and what's sort of impact that could have on capacity going forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think as we look at Europe, I think we're seeing the same trends in Europe as we're seeing in the U.S. That late model used equipment is up 5% or so or year-over-year. So very similar trends. In terms of repossessions, I can only comment. We've seen gra
componenttext: I think as we look at Europe, I think we're seeing the same trends in Europe as we're seeing in the U.S. That late model used equipment is up 5% or so or year-over-year. So very similar trends. In terms of repossessions, I can only comment. We've seen gradual improvement in the performance of our portfolio. We evaluate and want to work with our customers to achieve full pay up. But if the situation is not possible, then we try and find the quickest solution for the best economic result.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think it has really any effect on production or what we're doing, I mean it's just a small part of the business.
componenttext: I don't think it has really any effect on production or what we're doing, I mean it's just a small part of the business.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then we all line up pretty good three-step process here ahead of recovery. Sounds like in America, or North America or the U.S. were kind of early in step two. Can you just give your perspective on when you think things shift over into step three and
componenttext: And then we all line up pretty good three-step process here ahead of recovery. Sounds like in America, or North America or the U.S. were kind of early in step two. Can you just give your perspective on when you think things shift over into step three and then, maybe some perspective on where you think Europe is along that timeline?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think in terms of the pretty normal three-step process we have here, it's probably going to be later this year. And it's hard to pinpoint, obviously, there's a lot of economic inputs that have to be factored in and things are changing every week in many
componenttext: I think in terms of the pretty normal three-step process we have here, it's probably going to be later this year. And it's hard to pinpoint, obviously, there's a lot of economic inputs that have to be factored in and things are changing every week in many different industries as you know. In Europe, I'd say they're probably a little bit behind where North America is right now. But then I would also just add that they don't have the impact of transitioning from one engine model to another. So that could be a positive in the European market. So probably slightly behind. But they're both moving forward on the three-step process.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you still get a sense that there's a greater overcapacity situation in Europe to work through relative to the U.S.?
componenttext: Do you still get a sense that there's a greater overcapacity situation in Europe to work through relative to the U.S.?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there hasn't been too many factories decommissioned. As you know, we permanently shut our Nashville factory in the U.S. But in Europe, everybody's still has factories in place. Certainly, employees have been let go but structurally, the industry is
componenttext: Well, there hasn't been too many factories decommissioned. As you know, we permanently shut our Nashville factory in the U.S. But in Europe, everybody's still has factories in place. Certainly, employees have been let go but structurally, the industry is probably pretty much the same as it was a couple of years ago.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then if you look at a from truck or freight hauling capacity, you get a sense that there's more of a surplus in Europe than in the U.S. or closer to equilibrium there?
componenttext: And then if you look at a from truck or freight hauling capacity, you get a sense that there's more of a surplus in Europe than in the U.S. or closer to equilibrium there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would agree. I think U.S, North America is probably in a little bit better shape. Canada is in good shape economically. Mexico's starting to recover, although different things going on. And Europe plunged much more dramatically into recession. And
componenttext: Yes, I would agree. I think U.S, North America is probably in a little bit better shape. Canada is in good shape economically. Mexico's starting to recover, although different things going on. And Europe plunged much more dramatically into recession. And that was a real shock to the system that they're now coming out of.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Basili Alukos with Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Basili Alukos with Morningstar.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Kind of going back to an earlier question. Maybe asked a little differently, you mentioned the 1,500 MX engine orders. Can you talk about, I guess what timeframe are those engines are? Basically, what I'm trying to get is kind of what percentage of your t
componenttext: Kind of going back to an earlier question. Maybe asked a little differently, you mentioned the 1,500 MX engine orders. Can you talk about, I guess what timeframe are those engines are? Basically, what I'm trying to get is kind of what percentage of your total truck purchases that represents?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Those are over 12 months in terms of where the customers, where they lay them out on a monthly basis. Of course, that's starting this summer. So this summer to next summer is the way I'd realistically look at it. But at this time, it's closing in on 5% of
componenttext: Those are over 12 months in terms of where the customers, where they lay them out on a monthly basis. Of course, that's starting this summer. So this summer to next summer is the way I'd realistically look at it. But at this time, it's closing in on 5% of our orders and hopefully, that will increase.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess, correct me if I'm wrong, I've heard something that maybe the companies about 50% is kind of the goal. Ultimately they have...
componenttext: And I guess, correct me if I'm wrong, I've heard something that maybe the companies about 50% is kind of the goal. Ultimately they have...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Over time, sure, absolutely. I think, to look at the industry as a barometer, you can see what the competitors have. They all have their own in-house engines, a number of them still purchase third-party engines and you can see what their percentages are.
componenttext: Over time, sure, absolutely. I think, to look at the industry as a barometer, you can see what the competitors have. They all have their own in-house engines, a number of them still purchase third-party engines and you can see what their percentages are.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I was just trying to get a sense of kind of where it is now versus kind of...
componenttext: I was just trying to get a sense of kind of where it is now versus kind of...

componenttextpreview: It's early days, it's a very exciting journey but it's early days.
componenttext: It's early days, it's a very exciting journey but it's early days.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about kind of your three-tier turnaround, I guess, of how the trucking industry works. How closer do you follow the Truck Tonnage index? I've heard mixed reviews from different carriers themselves, kind of as to the validity of that...
componenttext: You talked about kind of your three-tier turnaround, I guess, of how the trucking industry works. How closer do you follow the Truck Tonnage index? I've heard mixed reviews from different carriers themselves, kind of as to the validity of that...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a great question and it's certainly one input is the way I put it.
componenttext: That's a great question and it's certainly one input is the way I put it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: But it's not something that you're kind of obsessed over?
componenttext: But it's not something that you're kind of obsessed over?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: We try not to obsess over anything except outstanding product quality and shareholder return.
componenttext: We try not to obsess over anything except outstanding product quality and shareholder return.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Back on the 13-liter engine, from what I what understand 13-liter engines are more fuel-efficient. And one of the reasons that they will be taken a hold in Europe is just doing what the geography, it's a lot smaller. And U.S., is a kind of more open road,
componenttext: Back on the 13-liter engine, from what I what understand 13-liter engines are more fuel-efficient. And one of the reasons that they will be taken a hold in Europe is just doing what the geography, it's a lot smaller. And U.S., is a kind of more open road, 15-liter engine is more desirable because of the power. At what point, do you have a sense of what price per gallon of diesel? I know we recently approached $3. But what price do you think the market share shifts their preferences to a more fuel-efficient engine?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at the pricing per gallon, you obviously have to translate that from liters and kilometers to miles. But in Europe, you can have anywhere from literally, $5 to $10 per gallon depending on when you're traveling. That will have an impact.
componenttext: Well, if you look at the pricing per gallon, you obviously have to translate that from liters and kilometers to miles. But in Europe, you can have anywhere from literally, $5 to $10 per gallon depending on when you're traveling. That will have an impact. And we have a wonderfully attractive low price for a gallon of diesel in North America. How long that will last is obviously open to much discussion. But over time, it will most likely go up and there will be more interest in 13-liter engines.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Tim Denoyer with Wolfe Trahan.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Tim Denoyer with Wolfe Trahan.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to PACCAR's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Mr. Robin Easton, PACCAR's Treasurer. Mr. Easton, please go ahead.
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to PACCAR's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Mr. Robin Easton, PACCAR's Treasurer. Mr. Easton, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Robin Easton, Treasurer of PACCAR. And joining me this morning are Mark Pigott, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Ron Armstrong, Senior Vice President
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Robin Easton, Treasurer of PACCAR. And joining me this morning are Mark Pigott, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Ron Armstrong, Senior Vice President; and Michael Barkley, Vice President, Controller.
As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media participating, we request that they participate in a listen-only mode. Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general economic and competitive conditions that may affect expected results.
I would now like to introduce Mark Pigott.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. PACCAR today reported improved revenues and net income for the second quarter of 2010. PACCAR's second quarter sales and Financial Services revenue were $2.46 billion compared to $1.85 billion in the second quarter of 2009, a 33% improvement
componenttext:
Good morning. PACCAR today reported improved revenues and net income for the second quarter of 2010. PACCAR's second quarter sales and Financial Services revenue were $2.46 billion compared to $1.85 billion in the second quarter of 2009, a 33% improvement. Net income improved to $99 million compared to $26 million a year ago. I'm very proud of our 16,000 employees who have delivered outstanding performance to our shareholders and customers in an uneven and unsettled global economy. PACCAR's financial results reflect the benefits of higher truck deliveries worldwide and a continued improvement in aftermarket parts sales and Financial Services results. However, the North American and European truck markets remained at historically low levels. In the U.S. and Canada, our customers are starting to adjust to the higher- priced vehicles that have resulted from the EPA 2010 emission change. The European truck registrations for the second quarter improved 17% compared to the first, but despite that favorable increase, the European truck market year-over-year is still down.
We expect the 15-ton market registrations in Europe to be between 160,000 units and 170,000 units this year, comparable to the 168,000 units last year. U.S. and Canadian retail truck sales are estimated to improve to a range of 110,000 to 130,000 units this year compared to 108,000 last year. While the global economic outlook is still uneven, the truck market is stabilizing. PACCAR truck build in the third quarter is expected to be slightly better than the second quarter. I would note that production at our DAF factories in Europe will have their regularly scheduled two-week summer shutdown.
We discussed during the analyst call in April the three-step process that the truck industry usually progresses as it recovers from a recession. First is improvement in parts and service, second in used truck values and third is more truck orders. In the U.S. and Canada, parts sales were up 10% to 15%, and used truck pricing increased 10%. The good news is that industry new truck orders for the first six months compared to a year ago are up 30%. Many of the orders are for production during the next six to 12 months. In Europe, a similar situation with parts business and used truck pricing improving by 10% to 15%. In Europe, as I previously noted, new truck sales are 15% lower than last year due to a slow first quarter, but the second half of the year should be up 20% compared to 2009.
More good news is that DAF is the leader in the European market for on-highway tractor sales and has now achieved a record overall market share of 16.3%, the second highest market share in Europe. It's been a wonderful success story over the last decade for DAF.
DAF is steadily progressing toward its medium-term goal of 20% market share in Europe. DAF heavy truck production is up 25% from first to second quarter this year and we expect that their production will be up 25% for the remainder of the year. Kenworth and Peterbilt build rates will be up 10% to 15% from the second to the third quarter.
Our customers are benefiting from a 7% year-on-year improvement in freight volumes, higher freight rates and stable diesel prices. They continue to increase the utilization of their fleets, which in turn is driving increased aftermarket parts and service business for our dealers. PACCAR's aftermarket parts sales increased to $538 million for the second quarter, the highest level since the third quarter of 2008.
Turning to margins, margins for trucks was primarily driven by higher pricing due to improved demand. PACCAR's strong balance sheet and positive cash flow have enabled the company to continuously reinvest in the business, enhance operating efficiency and develop innovative new products such as the PACCAR MX diesel engine. I'm pleased to note that we're now installing the MX engine in approximately 15% of Kenworth and Peterbilt vehicles. Assembly of the PACCAR MX engines began last month at our industry-leading manufacturing facility in Columbus, Mississippi. Early feedback from our customers of the PACCAR MX engine has been excellent. On a broader scale in the U.S. and Canada, the substantial majority of Kenworth and Peterbilt trucks are being produced with the EPA 2010 engines. I know a number of you are interested in it, but there appears to be about a 5% shift to 13-liter engines year-on-year.
PACCAR Financial Services revenues were $239 million in the second quarter compared to $247 million a year ago, reflecting a lower level of assets. PACCAR's Financial second quarter pretax income was $34 million, more than double the $16 million earned in Q2 of 2009. This was achieved due to better finance margins and a reduction in the provision for credit losses. The credit loss provision for the second quarter 2010 was $20.2 million compared to $29.1 million in 2009.
PACCAR's conservative approach to business complimented by its excellent credit ratings enables PACCAR Financial to offer competitive financing to Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF dealers and customers. The ongoing turmoil in the commercial real estate market is impacting regional banks in the U.S. which limits their ability to offer financing to truck customers, good news for PACCAR Financial. PACCAR Financial has excellent access to commercial paper and the medium-term note markets. Last month, PACCAR Financial sold a three-year $250 million fixed rate note at a rate of 2.1%. Also during the quarter, PACCAR completed the renewal of a $2 billion credit facility.
PACCAR's investment of $3.8 billion in the last decade has enabled the company to enhance its operating efficiency, develop new products, strengthen its dealer network and become an industry leader in information technology. As we all can see, from our iPads and newspapers and television every day, there continue to be many challenges facing the world economies. The global economic environment is still unsettled. However, PACCAR's balanced approach in all phases of the business cycle positions us to generate improving results for our shareholders as the global economy recovers. Thank you. Look forward to your questions.

componenttext: The thing that pops out immediately is the real strong gross margin performance in the quarter. Can you maybe help us understand, attribute that?  I’m sure part of it's driven by better volumes, but is there input cost benefits in there or anything else that you can point to that drove that good margin?

componenttext: Well, we commented in the opening statement gross margin was really driven primarily by some increased volume and better pricing, particularly as there’s been increased demand throughout the marketplace.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010

componenttext: Are you able to get margin on some of the higher-priced trucks with the new engines? I know that the cost has been passed through, but is there any margin, whatever it is, $8,000 to $10,000 increase?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's an $8,000 to $10,000 increase. We're starting to see slightly improved margins as the overall market is getting a little bit stronger. It's still a challenge for many of our customers to recognize that $8,000 to $10,000 price increase, but as th
componenttext: Yes, it's an $8,000 to $10,000 increase. We're starting to see slightly improved margins as the overall market is getting a little bit stronger. It's still a challenge for many of our customers to recognize that $8,000 to $10,000 price increase, but as the freight business improves, as their freight rates are increasing, as there's a little bit more business for our customers, they’re starting to see the benefits of it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I noticed a top headline today in one of the trade rags about fleets raising driver pay and I know in the past, you guys have talked about your premium brands being sort of a driver retention tool, which I guess when turnover was pretty low, that wasn
componenttext: And I noticed a top headline today in one of the trade rags about fleets raising driver pay and I know in the past, you guys have talked about your premium brands being sort of a driver retention tool, which I guess when turnover was pretty low, that wasn't probably as attractive a prospect. But now it looks that things are kind of turning the other way. Can you maybe address that?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. A number of our customers are increasing their pay somewhat, although there are still a fair number of potential candidates out there, particularly as the housing/construction market is at 50-year lows. But all these fleets want the best drivers that
componenttext: Yes. A number of our customers are increasing their pay somewhat, although there are still a fair number of potential candidates out there, particularly as the housing/construction market is at 50-year lows. But all these fleets want the best drivers that are available in the marketplace and using a Kenworth, Peterbilt or DAF product as an inducement to join their fleet is always a great idea and we encourage it.

componenttext: They’re at about five- or six-year lows, so our dealers are in great shape making strong profits as the Parts & Service business returns, used truck pricing is improving and they're in, very, very good shape financially.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s Chase Becker in for Jamie. Just a bigger-picture question on the announcement of DAF in South America, I know obviously this is probably not a huge near-term impact, but was wondering kind of if you could speak to longer-term strategy and kind of t
componenttext: It’s Chase Becker in for Jamie. Just a bigger-picture question on the announcement of DAF in South America, I know obviously this is probably not a huge near-term impact, but was wondering kind of if you could speak to longer-term strategy and kind of the investments that you feel that you need to make to be a meaningful player in that market?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s a great question.  I’m glad you brought it up. As you've seen from the reports, DAF has really become one of the major leaders in the European market, Western and Central Europe, now over 16% market share; great product, great dealers and reall
componenttext: That’s a great question.  I’m glad you brought it up. As you've seen from the reports, DAF has really become one of the major leaders in the European market, Western and Central Europe, now over 16% market share; great product, great dealers and really a terrific company. So as we are more comfortable with the strengths of what's going on in Europe, we're taking a look at South America. And we've sold in South America particularly with our Kenworth brand for many decades, but in America Sur region, which is most of the product being sold in South America, we've only sold in very limited numbers. So recently in the last few years as we evaluate growth opportunities, that seems to be a very strong candidate. Most likely, we'll take a manufacturing facility in order to meet local content regulations and also to qualify for some of the national finance programs that are available to customers in Brazil and Argentina. And as you've heard from many of our competitors, they seem to be gaining most of their profitability from the strong South American market. We compete against these same competitors around the world and do very well. So I think over time, we should have a very strong, profitable and growing presence in South America.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you care to touch on the potential timing of a manufacturing facility?
componenttext: Did you care to touch on the potential timing of a manufacturing facility?

componenttextpreview: They usually take a couple of years to get up and running and in place, but we will see what happens.
componenttext: They usually take a couple of years to get up and running and in place, but we will see what happens.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the material cost side, sounds like not seeing much headwinds right now, but wondering what your expectations are for the back half of the year. One of your suppliers was talking about it this morning?
componenttext: Just on the material cost side, sounds like not seeing much headwinds right now, but wondering what your expectations are for the back half of the year. One of your suppliers was talking about it this morning?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we track all of the major commodities around the world and obviously, now things have slowed. We have very good relations with all of our suppliers, dealing with commodity pricing. We have long-term agreements with them that hopefully will minimize
componenttext: Well, we track all of the major commodities around the world and obviously, now things have slowed. We have very good relations with all of our suppliers, dealing with commodity pricing. We have long-term agreements with them that hopefully will minimize the impact of the pricing swings. So at this time, minimal impact, but you can never tell as the world may go on a different tangent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Henry Kirn with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Henry Kirn with UBS.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you chat about how Europe trended through the quarter? If you saw improvements as the quarter went on?
componenttext: Could you chat about how Europe trended through the quarter? If you saw improvements as the quarter went on?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Europe started out slow for the whole industry in the first quarter. The second quarter definitely gained some momentum. As I said, it's up 17% second quarter to first. And orders continue to be good. Obviously, some countries are stronger than othe
componenttext: Sure. Europe started out slow for the whole industry in the first quarter. The second quarter definitely gained some momentum. As I said, it's up 17% second quarter to first. And orders continue to be good. Obviously, some countries are stronger than others. Some of the southern countries, Spain and Italy, are still challenged, but a little more confidence among our customers. Our dealers, once again, are in very good shape in Europe as they are in North America. So they're continuing to invest and add new service facilities, which help to grow our business. And I think as I shared with you, our DAF production is up about 25%. Some of that is obviously gaining market share as people really enjoy the DAF product. And I think the European market is steadily improving, but even with that, we're looking for the number of registrations this year to be comparable, maybe a little bit more than last year, but 2011 could be better again.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there anything you can highlight for either a segment of the market or a geography where you're gaining some of the share?
componenttext: Is there anything you can highlight for either a segment of the market or a geography where you're gaining some of the share?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are now number one in Europe in the On-highway Tractor segment, so that's the vehicles that you see up and down the motorways. That's been a very excellent result and a very long process of developing the right product for our customers. A growth
componenttext: Well, we are now number one in Europe in the On-highway Tractor segment, so that's the vehicles that you see up and down the motorways. That's been a very excellent result and a very long process of developing the right product for our customers. A growth opportunity for us is continuing to grow in the Off-highway or Construction segment. That tends to be a little bit more regionalized. Certainly the biggest market would be Germany and I think we still have a few competitors in Germany that seem to have a strong presence there. But overall, Northern Europe, DAF is doing well in every country. If we're not number one, most likely we're number two. So we see continued growth opportunities as we add more service facilities. We continue to invest in new products. We've got Euro 6 coming up in 2013. It’s going to be another exciting inflection point for our industry. So just good, steady progress. Excellent team.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Volkmann of Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Volkmann of Jefferies & Company.

componenttext: You provided some helpful detail here, Mark, overall, but also I'm going to ask with respect to your production volumes as we go forward, I think you mentioned Kenworth and Peterbilt would be up 10% to 15% in the third quarter. You reminded us about the DAF shutdown. Should I read that to be DAF is maybe flattish in the third quarter?

componenttextpreview: I think that's an excellent assessment.
componenttext: I think that's an excellent assessment.
